Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Story: I stared at my phone, the message from my mother glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, you’re leading the family ceremony tonight. It means a lot to your grandparents.” My heart thudded with the weight of their expectations. I knew how important it was to them, how much they counted on me to keep our traditions alive. But as I glanced at the stack of packages in the back of my van, my work phone buzzed with another notification—urgent delivery, signature required, no exceptions. The address was across town, and the recipient had already called twice, anxious about the package’s safety. My boss had made it clear: no failed deliveries, no shortcuts. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides, my family’s pride and my job’s demands pulling me in opposite directions. My hands trembled as I gripped the steering wheel, torn between the duty to my family and the responsibility to my job, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
